text:
Hey Kristin!

I usually see this packaged as either a one-time set-up thing ("I'll get your strategy off the ground") or a retainer ("I'll set you up and help you manage it from there.") Or a combination of both. For example: here's a fee for the initial strategy and then here's a fee for ongoing support.

I've seen monthly retainer prices range from $1k to way way higher, depending on niche, experience level, deliverables, and value.

Way to go taking on your first content strategy client!

text: A bit late, but I'm reading Radical Candor and really enjoying it

elements.text: A bit late, but I'm reading Radical Candor and really enjoying it

text: <@UQFUS4GQP> _extremely agree_ with folks above saying not to quote rates hourly to the client, but working out an hourly rate for yourself internally can be a good way to establish a floor - the bare minimum you'd *need* to charge in order to make the project work out economically. Just estimate roughly how long you think the project will take, multiply that by 1.25-1.5X (to correct for the fact that we humans are weirdly over-optimistic about how long it will take us to do things), and then multiply THAT number by what you want/need to be getting paid per hour.

elements.text: with folks above saying not to quote rates hourly to the client, but working out an hourly rate for yourself internally can be a good way to establish a floor - the bare minimum you'd

to charge in order to make the project work out economically. Just estimate roughly how long you think the project will take, multiply that by 1.25-1.5X (to correct for the fact that we humans are weirdly over-optimistic about how long it will take us to do things), and then multiply THAT number by what you want/need to be getting paid per hour.

text: If you're used to being a salaried employee, you also want to multiply by 1.3X to make room for overhead (healthcare, any tools you use for work, and of course, lovely, lovely self-employment taxes)

elements.text: If you're used to being a salaried employee, you also want to multiply by 1.3X to make room for overhead (healthcare, any tools you use for work, and of course, lovely, lovely self-employment taxes)

text:
In line with Katie's awesome advice, here's a Twitter thread I reference often for help with maths. It starts with day rate but gets into hourly. My only caveat is _don't_ divide your day rate by 8 to get your hourly. Divide it by 5 or even 4, because that's more realistic for sustainable billable hours and intense creative output.

<https://twitter.com/XCK3D/status/1093937746958143488>

text:
Hi all. Hope it's okay that I'm posting this here :-)

I'm hosting a webinar, "The Hidden Human Psychology of Successful Content Marketing" next Tuesday (1/21) with Advisable.

It was inspired by the many questions I receive about how demonstrate the value of content marketing, financially, to stakeholders. I have deep experiences building models that demonstrate this connection and am excited to share this framework publicly for the first time.

Please join me if you're looking to  align the transactional goals of your day marketing and branding initiatives with bigger-picture human interest motives in our Fourth Industrial Revolution world.

You'll come away with:
:raised_hands: A formula, based on 6 unique human psychology drivers, that can help you create a magnetic, loved brand.
:sunglasses: An understanding of how to make your content more useful and functional.
:upside_down_face: A technique to help you identify and resolve hidden friction-points that are inhibiting growth.
:earth_americas:Bigger stories to tell about your company, through the content you're already creating every day.
:hammer_and_pick: A set of case studies that will equip you with an actionable toolkit to implement in your day to day.

I will also share a quantitative framework for capturing ROI, that I've used for the last 6 years in organizations ranging from fortune 500 companies to startups, governments, and institutional investment teams.

<https://lnkd.in/eBfT6-A>

If you can't attend but are interested, please sign up, and I'll send you the recording.
